items.title: Will my social media posts really help my career?
items.author: Delia Cai, Steffi Cao
items.summary:
- Social media can promote art but isn't crucial for artist development; honing skills is more important.
- Everyone feels pressure to showcase their lives on social media; it's essential to find a balance.
- Connections in creative industries matter, but one shouldn't stress over online appearances.
- Social media can serve as a business card and humanizes you to potential collaborators.
- Choosing not to post on social media is okay, but maintaining an updated profile is beneficial for visibility.
- Proper Venmo etiquette involves proactive communication about payments to maintain friendships.

items.title: [Streaming](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=streaming) is finally profitable. It offers a lesson in patience
items.author: Henry Chandonnet
items.summary:
- Streaming services have recently become profitable after years of losses, with [Netflix](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=netflix) leading the industry.
- Spotify reported its first full year of profitability in February 2025, boosting its stock by 13%.
- Netflix's profit margin reached 22%, totaling $8.71 billion in profits from $39 billion in revenue.
- Smaller streamers like Max and Disney+ have also reported profitability after significant financial losses in prior years.
- The article emphasizes the importance of patience in technology investments, suggesting that emerging tech sectors may follow a similar trajectory to streaming.

items.title: [Meta](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=meta)’s AI randomly tried to throw a weird party for me—that I never asked for
items.summary:
- The author posted on Facebook about the return of [Puppy Monkey Baby](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=puppy%20monkey%20baby) after seeing it in a Super Bowl LIX ad.
- Meta's AI created an event titled "Puppy Monkey Baby Returns!" with details generated by AI, including the time and date.
- The event described a fun-filled evening with performances, giveaways, and surprises, meant to celebrate Puppy Monkey Baby's return.

items.title: OpenAI shouldn’t accept Elon Musk’s $97 billion bid to buy it
items.summary:
- Elon Musk's group has made a $97.4 billion bid to buy the non-profit arm of OpenAI.
- Musk’s offer is significantly lower than recent valuations, which were as high as $260 billion.
- OpenAI is currently engaged in ongoing legal disputes with Musk over his earlier involvement with the organization.
- Sam Altman jokingly responded to the bid, suggesting OpenAI would buy Twitter for $9.74 billion instead.

items.title: Elon Musk’s $97 billion OpenAI bid would give the DOGE chief even more power in the AI race
items.summary:
- A group led by Elon Musk has made a $97.4 billion unsolicited bid for OpenAI's nonprofit arm.
- Other investors include Valor Equity Partners, Baron Capital, and CEO Ari Emanuel among others.
- Musk's bid escalates tensions with OpenAI CEO Sam Altman over the organization's shift from nonprofit to profit-driven goals.

items.title: This app combines Wikipedia and TikTok to fight doomscrolling
items.author: Tyler Angert, Isaac Gemal
items.summary:
- Tyler Angert proposed the idea of a scrolling Wikipedia page, leading to the creation of the app WikiTok by Isaac Gemal.
- WikiTok presents users with a stream of Wikipedia article stubs, encouraging knowledge discovery without invasive tracking.
- The app features a TikTok-style interface, random Wikipedia articles, and supports article previews in 14 languages, with plans for community-driven features.

items.title: [NASA](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=nasa) astronauts are streaming live on Twitch from space. Here’s how to watch
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- [NASA](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=nasa) will host its first Twitch event with astronauts streaming live from the International Space Station (ISS) on February 12 at 11:45 a.m. ET.
- Flight engineer Don Pettit and NASA astronaut Matt Dominick will participate, discussing life in orbit and ongoing research in microgravity.
- Viewers can interact by asking questions during the stream, marking a new way for NASA to engage with the public about space exploration and [STEM](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=stem) opportunities.

items.title: What exactly is the point of the AI Action Summit?
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- The AI Action Summit is being held in Paris, hosted by French president Emmanuel Macron, with Vice President JD Vance in attendance.
- The summit is focused on discussing the future of AI amidst rapid developments in the field, including the U.S.'s $500 billion Project Stargate.
- This is the third major summit on AI governance, aiming to foster diplomatic dialogue and address the societal impact of AI, despite criticism about the speed of government responses to private sector advancements.

items.title: AI summit in Paris brings together [Big Tech](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=bigtech) and U.S. VP Vance
items.author: Sylvie Corbet, Aamer Madhani
items.summary:
- Major world leaders are meeting for an AI summit in Paris with participants from around 100 countries.
- High-profile attendees include U.S. Vice President JD Vance and Chinese Vice Premier Zhang Guoqing.
- The summit focuses on advancing [AI](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=artificial%20intelligence) in sectors like health, education, and culture.
- A global public-private partnership named "Current AI" will be launched to support large-scale initiatives.
- French President Macron emphasized the importance of AI for enhancing human living conditions.
- Vance plans to discuss diplomatic issues, including the Russia-Ukraine conflict, during the summit.
- India’s Modi is cohosting the summit to involve more global actors and prevent a U.S.-China AI rivalry.

items.title: [Credo AI](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=credo-ai)’s vision for ethical and transparent AI governance
items.author: Brendan Vaughn
items.summary:
- Credo AI's CEO discusses [AI governance](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=ai-governance) trends.
- Interviewed by Brendan Vaughn, editor-in-chief of ‘Fast Company.’
- The discussion took place at the World Economic Forum 2025.

items.title: Chess.com Launches Friends and Family Subscription Plan
items.summary:
- Chess.com introduces a friends and family subscription plan for $199.99 a year.
- The plan offers access for up to four people, providing features like ad-free experience and chess lessons.
- Launched in January, the plan aims to foster loyalty among groups of players.
- CEO Erik Allebest emphasizes the plan benefits both consumers and the business, boosting retention rates.

items.title: Roblox joins $27 million industry nonprofit to support online safety
items.summary:
- Roblox, Google, OpenAI, and Discord cofound nonprofit Robust Open Online Safety Tools (ROOST).
- ROOST will fund free, open-source tools for online safety in internet businesses.
- Roblox has implemented measures to restrict inappropriate messaging for its 85 million daily active users, utilizing AI and automation for real-time monitoring.
- An open-source AI model developed by Roblox detects various forms of disallowed content and supports multiple languages, with further development expected by 2025.

items.title: Why tomorrow’s breakthroughs will come from polyintelligent thinking
items.summary:
- The convergence of human intelligence, artificial intelligence, and nature's intelligence is leading to groundbreaking discoveries.
- Nature's intelligence, demonstrated through learning and adaptation, plays a crucial role alongside human and machine intelligence.
- The concept of 'polyintelligence' combines these three forms to address complex global challenges and has transformative potential in fields like biotechnology.
- The Human Genome Project exemplifies the benefits of this integrated approach, enabling advancements in medicine and genetics.

items.title: Find the perfect free Zoom background at these 3 sites
items.author: Doug Aamoth
items.summary:
- The article discusses creative and functional Zoom backgrounds to enhance meetings.
- Three websites are highlighted offering nearly 500,000 free Zoom backgrounds: [Pexels](https://www.pexels.com/search/zoom%20background/), [Unsplash](https://unsplash.com/s/photos/zoom-backgrounds?license=free).
- Pexels is noted for its vast collection of over 450,000 photos and videos, with filter and sorting options for users.
- Unsplash offers around 10,000 backgrounds, focusing on modern and polished appearances for virtual meetings.

items.title: EV Winter is here. Carmakers are betting on a thaw
items.summary:
- The transition to electric vehicles (EVs) is the auto industry's biggest transformation since the introduction of cars.
- Buyers are not purchasing EVs at the expected rates, leading to heavy financial losses for automakers.
- Despite the current challenges, numerous battery plants and EV factories are being established in the Midwest and South.
- Automakers can't abandon their EV strategies due to competition from Tesla and emerging Chinese manufacturers.
- The transition requires significant overhauls in supply chains and costly battery technologies, which remain a major expense for EVs.

items.title: How Apple could work with DeepSeek to pull ahead in the AI race
items.summary:
- DeepSeek has gained attention for its AI capabilities, impacting perceptions of American tech giants like OpenAI and Google.
- Apple's potential benefit from DeepSeek's arrival is often discussed, suggesting that the partnership could be advantageous.
- A partnership with DeepSeek could help Apple gain access to the Chinese market, which is crucial for iPhone sales.
- Apple aims to integrate Apple Intelligence into its services but faces regulatory challenges in China, prompting possible collaborations with existing local AI providers.

items.title: This app sends faxes for free from your iPhone, Android device, Mac, or PC
items.summary:
- A new app allows users to send faxes for free from various devices including iPhone, Android, Mac, and PC.
- Despite the rise of digital alternatives, there are still situations where faxing is necessary.
- The article humorously addresses the outdated nature of faxing while providing a practical solution for occasional fax needs.

items.title: ‘It just didn’t go the way I planned’: Hawk Tuah girl breaks silence after crypto scandal
items.author: Haliey Welch
items.summary:
- Haliey Welch, known as the Hawk Tuah girl, speaks out after cryptocurrency scandal in December 2024.
- She launched $HAWK memecoin on December 4, achieving a $490 million market cap before collapsing by $440 million in 20 minutes.
- Welch describes trusting a friend in the token launch, which she regrets as her biggest mistake, and expresses sorrow for those affected.
- FaZe Banks, who previously urged her to fire her team, revealed he agreed to a podcast appearance with conditional terms regarding market manipulation and the future of $HAWK.
- A leak from Welch’s team caused the podcast episode to be canceled unexpectedly, leading to fluctuating prices for $HAWK.

items.title: Amazon to pay nearly $4 million for allegedly taking drivers’ tips
items.summary:
- Amazon will pay nearly $4 million to settle claims of taking tips from delivery drivers.
- The settlement follows a lawsuit by D.C. Attorney General Brian L. Schwalb regarding misleading information about tip usage.
- This comes four years after a $61.7 million settlement with the FTC over similar allegations.
- The lawsuit claimed Amazon changed its payment model without informing drivers or customers, affecting those in the Amazon Flex program.
- The FTC's complaint highlighted that Amazon used tips to offset its reduced wages for drivers.

items.title: ‘A true victim of the Snapchat era’: Parents are resurfacing hilariously filtered baby photos from the 2010s
items.summary:
- Many parents are reminiscing about the mid-2010s and the prevalence of Snapchat filters in baby photos.
- TikToker @themkidzmama3 went viral for a video showcasing her daughter’s filtered baby photos, emphasizing the impact of the Snapchat filter culture.
- The video has garnered over 26.5 million views, sparking discussions about the future of photo albums and the potential for defiltering apps.

items.title: Meta’s Ray-Ban smart glasses are having their Super Bowl moment
items.summary:
- Meta has purchased two ad spots for Ray-Ban Meta smart glasses during Super Bowl, featuring Chris Hemsworth and Chris Pratt.
- Over one million units of Ray-Ban Meta glasses have been sold in 2024, with plans for more releases.
- New versions of smart glasses are set to be introduced later this year, including a model with a small display for notifications and translations.
- Meta's glasses include features like AI assistance, photo and video capture, and voice control.
- Despite previous backlashes against smart glasses, there has been surprisingly little pushback against Ray-Ban Meta glasses so far.

items.title: OpenAI launches cross-country search to build data center sites for the Stargate project
items.summary:
- OpenAI is seeking sites across 16 U.S. states to build data centers for the Stargate project, expanding from its Texas location.
- The company has issued a request for proposals for land and infrastructure, focusing on sites with energy and water access.
- The Stargate joint venture between OpenAI, Oracle, and Softbank aims to invest up to $500 billion in data center construction.
- Energy consumption of AI data centers is a concern, with discussions around renewable energy sources and carbon management plans.
- OpenAI plans to establish 5 to 10 campuses, actively exploring locations in states such as California, Florida, and New York.

items.title: These groups are pushing for the NFL to end facial recognition
items.author: Caitlin Seeley George
items.summary:
- Privacy groups Fight for the Future and Algorithmic Justice League are urging the NFL to stop using facial recognition in stadiums.
- A petition has been launched demanding an end to the use of facial recognition for stadium employees and vendors.
- Concerns include the invasion of privacy and possible unauthorized capture of fans’ images during events.
- Facial recognition technology raises risks of data breaches, with biometric data being more difficult to change than passwords.

items.title: ‘It’s not only centered around video anymore’: Zoom’s CEO explains the video conference giant’s next act
items.author: Eric Yuan
items.summary:
- Zoom has rebranded from "Zoom Video Communications Inc." to "Zoom Communications Inc."
- The company is expanding its offerings to include Team Chat, a collaborative document platform, business phone features, and an AI companion.
- CEO Eric Yuan discusses the shift in focus beyond video and the impact of AI on future work, along with changes in usage patterns due to the return to office.

items.title: Academic researchers are going to have to learn algospeak
items.summary:
- Researchers are restricted from using specific words such as 'excluded', 'historically', 'socioeconomic', 'systemic', and 'women' in funding pitches to the NSF.
- This is part of an initiative by the Trump administration aimed at reducing 'woke' research related to diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI).
- The vague guidelines are believed to be intentional, allowing the government to block desired research topics, potentially affecting various fields including biomedical and social sciences.
- Academics express concern that the restrictions may lead to a decline in research quality and innovation.
- Researchers might adapt by using 'algospeak', a tactic similar to rephrasing for social media to circumvent such restrictions.

items.title: Welcome to HillmanTok University, the digital HBCU inspired by ‘A Different World’
items.author: Cierra Hinton, Leah Barlow
items.summary:
- HillmanTok University offers free online courses inspired by the fictional HBCU from *A Different World*.
- Over 400 courses available, covering topics from herbalism to history.
- Founded by Cierra Hinton after a TikTok video by professor Leah Barlow went viral, gaining 4.3 million views.
- Courses are designed to mimic the educational experience of Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs).
- Features a school store selling merchandise, student IDs, and a school song by Kendrick Lamar.
- Despite challenges with regulation on TikTok, the movement aims to create a supportive educational community.

items.title: OpenAI picks Texas for ‘flagship’ data center in Stargate project
items.summary:
- OpenAI announces Texas as the flagship data center site for the Stargate project in partnership with SoftBank.
- The project is set to invest up to $500 billion to maintain the U.S. competitive edge in AI against China.
- President Donald Trump initiated the AI infrastructure investment initiative to support these efforts, which will create over 100,000 jobs.

items.title: Like TikTok, lawmakers want to ban DeepSeek from government devices
items.author: Josh Gottheimer, Darin LaHood
items.summary:
- Lawmakers introduced the 'No DeepSeek on Government Devices Act' to ban DeepSeek from federal devices.
- Concerns about surveillance and misinformation from the Chinese Communist Party were cited.
- The push for the ban follows DeepSeek's AI model development, raising concerns among U.S. policymakers.
- The legislation parallels previous actions taken against TikTok, which was also linked to national security risks.
- This comes amid growing competition between the U.S. and China in technological innovation.

items.title: Liberal TikTok Users Mock 'Conservative Girl' Makeup Trend
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- A bad 'conservative girl' makeup technique is trending on TikTok, gaining significant online traction since November.
- TikTok creator Suzanne Lambert's video showcasing the look has received five million views, highlighting traits like clumpy mascara and mismatched foundation.
- The trend reflects a generational divide in political preferences among women, with 53% of female voters backing Kamala Harris over Trump among other statistics.

items.title: Bluesky photo-sharing app Flashes launches in beta
items.author: Sebastian Vogelsang
items.summary:
- Flashes, a photo-sharing app linked to Bluesky, launched in beta this week but was pulled due to technical issues.
- Developer Sebastian Vogelsang announced that Apple is working on a fix.
- Flashes allows photo posts of up to four images and videos up to one minute long.
- Posts on Flashes will also show on Bluesky, and comments from Bluesky users will appear on Flashes.
- The app appeals to users looking to move away from Meta’s ecosystem and other large tech platforms.
- Bluesky has gained nearly 31 million users, particularly as dissatisfaction with social media management grows.
- 3,500 users signed up within the first hour of Flashes' launch before the app was closed for the time being.

items.title: This startup can measure custom insoles with just an iPhone camera
items.summary:
- Groov allows customers to scan their feet and shoes using an iPhone camera to create 3D models.
- The app uses machine learning algorithms to design custom insoles tailored to individual foot shapes.
- Insoles options include the Plush for everyday comfort, the Response model for athletes, and the Luxe for discreet replacements in high heels.

items.title: OpenAI’s “deep research” gives a preview of the AI agents of the future
items.summary:
- OpenAI introduced a new AI research assistant called “deep research” powered by its o3-mini model. 
- The tool is designed for professionals in fields requiring thorough research, such as finance and science, and is accessible only to Pro users for $200/month with a limit of 100 searches. 
- In tests, deep research produced a detailed 2,000-word essay on pain relief products and a summary of AI applications in cancer research, citing multiple sources. 
- Limitations were noted in the currency of scientific studies referenced, suggesting some results were outdated. 
- A study on AI’s role in mammogram analysis showed a 29% increase in early cancer detection when AI assisted radiologists.

items.title: Hundreds of rigged votes can skew AI model rankings on Chatbot Arena, study finds
items.author: Tianyu Pang
items.summary:
- New research shows it's possible to rig AI model rankings with just a few hundred votes.
- Study conducted by Tianyu Pang at Sea AI Lab examined Chatbot Arena, a crowdsourced AI benchmarking platform.
- Manipulating rankings can be done by casting a small number of votes, affecting public perceptions of model performance.

items.title: Airlines are finally embracing Apple’s air tags—which means lost luggage could be a thing of the past
items.summary:
- Apple partners with 15 airlines to help track lost luggage using AirTags.
- Over 2.8 million bags mishandled by U.S. airlines in 2023.
- New iOS 18.2 feature allows AirTag owners to share their bag's location easily with airline staff.

items.title: Try these tips to help your parents stay safe online
items.author: Paul Schreiber
items.summary:
- The article provides tips to help parents benefit from technology while maintaining their online safety.
- It addresses the need to protect against scams, malware, and unnecessary complexity in using tech.
- The content includes specific hardware recommendations, security steps, and practical implementation tips.

items.title: ‘Attractive people doing attractive things’: Members of this Instagram group dress up to make ‘old money’ content
items.summary:
- A viral X post features a video portraying a luxurious ‘old money’ lifestyle.  
- The video was called out as staged, revealing it's part of an exclusive group called the Tuxedo Society.  
- Founded by Riccardo Capotosti, the Tuxedo Society requires a significant income or net worth for membership.  
- Membership costs 6,000 euros annually, with an approval process including an introductory video call.  
- Influencers and a notable ‘old money’ model are among current members.

items.title: Oracle’s HR software now has AI to help with taxes and career planning
items.author: Jocelyn Mintz
items.summary:
- Oracle has introduced AI capabilities in its Human Capital Management software to optimize workplace productivity.
- The AI answers employee questions related to hiring, benefits, taxes, and career planning using truthful data from companies.
- By using AI, Oracle aims to reduce the workload of HR departments and enhance employee efficiency.
- Oracle started integrating AI into various applications in September and plans to include it in finance products by spring.

items.title: This copy trading app wants to produce the ‘next five Warren Buffetts’
items.author: Steven Wang
items.summary:
- Dub is an influencer-driven investment app allowing users to copy portfolios of famous traders for a fee.
- Users can access portfolios of notable figures like Rep. Nancy Pelosi and Bill Ackman for $9.99/month or $89.99/year.
- The platform aims to identify and promote the next generation of top fund managers through its creator program.

items.title: In a time crunch? 3 ways GenAI can come through in a clutch
items.author: AJ Shankar
items.summary:
- Generative AI (GenAI) significantly impacts various fields, particularly healthcare and law, by enhancing efficiency and saving time.
- In legal settings, GenAI speeds up document analysis, helping lawyers resolve cases faster and more effectively, as seen in Cole, Scott & Kissane's experiences.
- GenAI transforms the discovery phase of lawsuits, allowing rapid analysis of large amounts of electronic documents, thereby reducing costs by over 50%.
- Legal professionals are using GenAI tools, likened to a 'smart intern', to quickly summarize complex tasks, streamlining their workflow.

items.title: Amazon’s Alexa generative AI upgrade is finally coming after delays
items.summary:
- Amazon will unveil its generative AI-powered Alexa voice service on February 26 in New York.
- This will be the first major upgrade to Alexa since its launch, with aims to enhance user interaction and increase monetization.
- The AI service can handle multiple prompts in sequence and act on users' behalf, surpassing the current single-request capability.
- A crucial decision meeting for the revamp is scheduled for February 14, focusing on its readiness for market.
- The upgrade faces challenges similar to those of existing generative AI chatbots, including the accuracy of responses.

items.title: Transportation Sec. Duffy suggests changing air traffic rules and antiquated tech
items.author: Sean Duffy
items.summary:
- U.S. Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy is reconsidering air traffic rules following a fatal Army helicopter-plane collision that killed 67 people.
- He criticized the military's use of helicopters near Reagan National Airport, suggesting alternatives like driving.
- The FAA has imposed new restrictions on helicopter flights around the airport until at least late February.

items.title: AI might run your next employee training
items.author: Tigran Sloyan
items.summary:
- Employers are concerned about Gen Z's lack of social skills for office interactions due to limited practice opportunities during the pandemic.
- CodeSignal has launched an AI-powered feature called Cosmo to help users practice business conversation skills independently.
- The platform previously focused on technical skills; the new addition enables practice of negotiations, feedback, and sales calls.

items.title: China’s DeepSeek web version is raising security alarms. Here’s why
items.author: Byron Tau
items.summary:
[ DeepSeek's web version may send user login data to China Mobile, a state-owned company. ]
[ Security researchers found obfuscated code linking DeepSeek to China Mobile, raising national security concerns. ]
[ The U.S. has previously denied China Mobile authority to operate in the U.S. due to national security risks. ]

items.title: Elon Musk’s China ties make a bad situation worse
items.summary:
* Elon Musk's control over government systems and activities raises concerns about his influence and legality.
* Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent granted Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) access to a sensitive federal payment system.
* Legal experts and lawmakers express alarm about the potential illegality of Musk's actions and his ties to China, posing national security risks.
* Senators Elizabeth Warren and Ron Wyden have called for an inquiry into the access granted to Musk's team.

items.title: The destruction going on at U.S. government sites is bad news for us all
Why this cybersecurity startup wants to watermark everything
items.author: Troy Batterberry
items.summary:
- EchoMark is a cybersecurity startup founded in 2022, focused on digital watermarking to protect sensitive information.
- The company has developed an API to integrate its watermarking tool with existing communication software.
- EchoMark aims to ensure that private information can be forensic watermarked and tied to the recipient's identity.
- The startup received $10 million in seed funding to expand its mission to watermark digital content.
- Founder Troy Batterberry, with a background in missile systems and technology at Microsoft, has a vision for personalized watermarking across various types of documents.

items.title: LinkedIn’s big bet on TikTok-style video is paying off in a big way
items.author: Laura Laurenzetti
items.summary:
- Short-form video is the fastest-growing category on LinkedIn, growing at twice the rate of other post formats.
- Total video viewership surged 36% in Q1 2025.
- New features include full-screen vertical video on desktop, swipeable carousels for topic searches, and easier following of creators.
- LinkedIn launched nano-learning courses for video creation skills.
- Video uploads increased by 34% year-over-year in Q4 2024, indicating successful engagement efforts.

items.title: You can try DeepSeek’s R1 through Perplexity—without the security risk
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Perplexity integrates Chinese company DeepSeek’s R1 model, allowing users to try it without data passing through DeepSeek’s app.
- CEO Aravind Srinivas claims DeepSeek’s models represent a revolutionary moment in AI, despite skepticism from some AI experts.
- Users can access DeepSeek via a menu in Perplexity's interface, which shows the model's "chain of thought" in real-time, a first for AI models.
- DeepSeek R1 avoids politically sensitive discussions and has less stringent data-sharing practices, keeping user data in the U.S. and Canada.

items.title: The value of Trump’s memecoin has dropped more than 75% since inauguration
items.author: Chris Morris
items.summary:
- Trump’s memecoin, $TRUMP, launched just before his inauguration, has seen a significant drop in value.
- The coin fell from an all-time high of $75.35 to $16.63, a loss of more than 75%.
- The market cap of $TRUMP is currently $3.3 billion, down from $14.5 billion prior to the inauguration.
- A memecoin launched by Melania Trump also saw a decline, dropping 88% since its peak.
- The sell-off of $TRUMP coincided with economic fears and ongoing tariff discussions, affecting overall cryptocurrency markets.

items.title: Robinhood halts Super Bowl betting contracts after CFTC request
items.summary:
- Robinhood announced the rollback of event contracts for betting on the Super Bowl after CFTC request.
- The decision comes one day after product launch; Robinhood expressed disappointment.
- CFTC did not classify Kalshi's football contracts as illegal; Robinhood is complying with their directive.
- The contracts were launched to 1% of Robinhood's users, with options for users to close positions or allow resolution.
- Event derivatives trading allows speculation on outcomes of various events like elections and economic releases.
